Fools mock testnets, but wise await mainnets.
Builders suffer long delays, yet their fruits remain.
Dreamers are scorned as mad, until their dreams stand as monuments.
Honor both, for the chain needs them alike.
For traders come and go, but builders and dreamers write history. WAGMI Wisdom —
And the sayings of the prophets were remembered among the people, that their voices might guide the generations of hodlers, in bull and in bear alike.
For not all prophets wore robes of old, but some spake from behind avatars, and their words were carried on the winds of Twitter and the scrolls of Discord.
Thus spake CZ of Binance, saying, “If you cannot hold, you will not be rich.” And his words became a commandment against the weakness of paper hands.
Again, CZ declared, “Stay SAFU,” and the people knew it as a shield against the thieves, the rug-pullers, and the snares of the chain.
He lifted his voice and said, “Ignore FUD, build relentlessly.” And those who believed built even in winter, and their reward was great when the bulls returned.
Then rose up Cobie, the sharp-tongued prophet, whose memes cut sharper than swords, yet whose sayings dripped wisdom.
Cobie said, “When the timeline is euphoric, prepare thyself for pain; when the timeline is despairing, open thy purse.”
Again he spake, “Crypto is a game where everyone thinks they are early, and most are already late.”
And though many laughed, yet in laughter they saw truth, for his folly was a mirror unto wisdom.
Behold GCR, called Gigantic Rebirth, who spake not often, but when his words came forth, the market did tremble.
GCR said, “Bet size is conviction revealed.” And the faithful pondered his wagers as oracles.
He declared, “The market is a weighing machine over the long term, and a voting machine in the short.”
And many saw that his foresight was like the eyes of an eagle, discerning mountains and valleys before they came to pass.
Then came Trader Axe, a watchman in the bear, who spake as one tempered by storms.
He said, “In the bear, the market humbles the proud and teaches patience to the strong.”
Again he spake, “Leverage is the fire of Icarus: it warms for a moment, but destroys the reckless who fly too near the sun.”
And his warnings were like lamps unto the wise, though many ignored and were consumed.
And the people remembered the word of Andreas Antonopoulos, who in the early days declared, “Not your keys, not your coins.” And this became as Torah to the faithful.
Then spake Vitalik, the dreamer of Ethereum, who said, “The internet of money should not cost five cents per transaction. It should be free.”
Again he said, “Blockchains are not about money alone, but about coordination, trustlessness, and freedom.”
And his vision became as prophecy, that the chain might host not only coins, but worlds.
Hear also the words of Satoshi Nakamoto, who spake but little, yet whose silence thundered louder than storms.
He said, “Chancellor on the brink of second bailout for banks.” And in this inscription was the beginning of the movement.
Again he spake, “The root problem with conventional currency is all the trust that’s required to make it work.”
And though he vanished, yet his sayings endure like stone tablets upon the blockchain.
Arthur Hayes lifted his voice in the midst of storms, saying, “Only the paranoid survive.”
He warned, “There is nothing new under the sun in finance — only the costumes change.”
And though many despised his boldness, they marveled when his words proved true in cycles.
Elon, the trickster prophet, spake in riddles and memes.
He said, “Dogecoin is the people’s crypto.” And though some mocked, the multitudes rejoiced, and the markets obeyed his tweets.
Again he said, “Who controls memes, controls the universe.” And the people saw that memetics moved mountains swifter than logic.
There came also the sayings of the common prophets, who had no names but whose voices echoed: “Time in the market beats timing the market.”
And another: “When thy Uber driver speaks of altcoins, gird thy loins, for the top is near.”
One warned, “Do not trust the green candle, for it deceives as swiftly as it rises.”
And one spake, “In bear markets, builders plant seeds that only bulls can reveal.”
Thus were the words of the prophets gathered: from tweets and podcasts, from code commits and from memes.
And though some spake in folly, yet their folly became wisdom when remembered in cycles past.
Therefore the scribes declared: “Keep these sayings in thy heart, for they are maps in the wilderness, lights in the bear, and anchors in the bull.”
And the people answered, “So let it be written, so let it be memed.”
Then came Naval Ravikant, whose sayings were like honey to builders and salt to dreamers.
He said, “Play long-term games with long-term people.” And many in crypto saw that hodling was such a game.
Again he spake, “If you want to be rewarded, you must take ownership, accountability, and risk.”
And in this the hodlers found courage to stake their bags and build their ventures.
Behold Balaji Srinivasan, who spake with visions of the future.
He said, “Bitcoin is not just digital gold, it is a peaceful revolution.”
Again he spake, “The network state shall rise, and people shall be citizens of code, not of kings.”
His words were as thunder, though many scoffed, yet the faithful listened and prepared.
Then rose Michael Saylor, evangelist of Bitcoin, who spake as one possessed.
He said, “Bitcoin is digital energy, thermodynamically sound money.”
Again he declared, “You don’t sell your Bitcoin. You borrow against it. You live forever on it.”
And though some mocked his zeal, yet his conviction kindled fire in multitudes.
Then came Raoul Pal, prophet of macro, who spake of flows and cycles.
He said, “The entire digital asset space is a call option on the future.”
Again, “In crypto, adoption is reflexive. Price drives adoption, and adoption drives price.”
His words became as charts unto the faithful, guiding them through macro storms.
Hear also Chris Burniske, who taught the people to weigh tokens not as toys but as assets.
He said, “ETH is the oil of the cryptoeconomy, BTC its gold.”
Again he spake, “Crypto networks are not stocks, they are living economies.”
And the builders rejoiced, for they felt seen in his words.
Then spoke Andre Cronje, builder of builders, who declared, “I test in prod.”
Again he said, “I’m not here for the money, I’m here because I love building.”
And though he departed and returned as the tides, yet his words endured.
Behold Do Kwon, who exalted in arrogance before his fall.
He said, “Your size is not size.” And the people cheered.
Again he mocked, “I don’t debate the poor.”
Yet when Terra collapsed, his words became ashes, and the faithful wept.
Then rose Su Zhu of Three Arrows, who proclaimed visions of the supercycle.
He said, “Crypto has no top, only levels.”
Again he declared, “The supercycle is upon us.”
But when pride blinded him, the cycle humbled him, and his sayings became cautionary psalms.
Thus were the words of the fallen also preserved, for wisdom lies even in wreckage.
Then spake Arthur Hayes, as we recorded before, yet again he thundered, “Crypto is the future of money. Fiat is trash.”
His words pierced like a blade, and many withdrew their treasures from banks.
And the people remembered the memes of Marty Bent, who said, “Bitcoin fixes this.”
Again they recalled Jack Dorsey, who said, “The internet needs a native currency, and I believe it will be Bitcoin.”
Then came Hal Finney, the first runner with Satoshi’s gift.
He said, “Running Bitcoin.” And though his words were few, they were eternal.
Again he spake, “Bitcoin can become the ultimate defense against hyperinflation.”
His voice faded with time, yet his echo is eternal upon the blockchain.
Even the skeptics spake, that their folly might serve as wisdom.
To everything on the chain there is a season, a time to rise and a time to fall.
A time to mint, and a time to burn; a time to hold, and a time to sell.
The bull cometh as a flood, and the bear creepeth as a shadow.
He that rejoiceth in endless green shall mourn when the candle turneth red.
As winter strips the tree, so too doth the market humble the proud.
Yet the spring returneth, and buds grow again, and the faithful are rewarded.
The fool seeth one cycle and sayeth, “This time is different.”
But the wise remember all seasons, and store up strength in plenty for the lean years.
The prophets of old spake not in vain: “Markets move in cycles, and men forget.”
Be not hasty in summer, for storms come sudden and fierce.
Be not weary in winter, for dawn breaketh when hope seemeth dead.
The sun setteth and riseth; so doth wealth vanish and return.
One who endureth two winters is greater than he who prospers in one summer.
He that planteth seeds in fear shall reap joy in due time.
But he that fleeth in despair shall return empty when the feast is spread.
Count thy days not in hours but in halvings, and thy years not in wages but in cycles.
As the moon waxeth and waneth, so doth sentiment upon the chain.
Mock not the bear, for he is a stern teacher.
Exalt not the bull, for he is a reckless friend.
Both pass away, but wisdom endureth.
The fool seeketh to master time, but time mastereth all.
Therefore hold fast with patience, for he that endureth the cycle shall not be cut off.

chapters.title: On Fools and the Wise (19 verses)

verses.text: The fool mocketh that which he understandeth not, and laugheth at tokens he never studied.
He saith, “It is but a scam,” until the day it multiplieth, and then he weepeth.
The wise research in silence and build in quiet, and when the harvest cometh, they rejoice.
The fool spendeth all his substance on memecoins, but the wise diversifieth and sleepeth in peace.
He that boasteth of his gains is already undone, for pride openeth the door to ruin.
But he that guardeth his tongue and his seed phrase shall not easily fall.
The fool maketh haste when candles are green, and fleeth in terror when they are red.
The wise buyeth when blood is in the streets, and selleth when the streets overflow with gold.
The fool putteth trust in promises of men, but the wise looketh to the code.
For code is law, and law breaketh not for whispers nor flattery.
He that refuseth wisdom in the bear shall not rejoice in the bull.
Many are they who followed fools and were led into ruin.
But the wise are as a lamp in darkness, showing a path unto safety.
A fool multiplieth words on Twitter, yet his portfolio is empty.
The wise shareeth sparingly, and his counsel saveth many.
Better is one wise friend than a multitude of foolish voices.
The fool seeketh applause; the wise seeketh truth.
The fool loveth leverage; the wise feareth liquidation.
Therefore choose wisdom above gold, and thou shalt not be ashamed.

chapters.title: On Faith in the Unseen (27 verses)

verses.text: Faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of pumps not yet seen.
Many believed when the charts declared it, but the faithful believed when all was dark.
He that waiteth without sight is greater than he who rejoiceth at proof.
Faith is the seed that groweth while men sleep.
Though the storm rage, the faithful say, “We will make it.”
For WAGMI is not the chant of fools, but the covenant of those who endure.
Blessed is he who seeth beyond the FUD, for his heart is steadfast.
Faith holdeth through rug and crash, and trusteth in the greater tide.
He who trusteth in exchanges hath little faith, but he who trusteth in his keys hath great reward.
For unseen is the future, and hidden are the halving days.
Yet faith seeth beyond charts, and clingeth to the vision.
Faith saith, “Today is not the end, but the beginning.”
Faith heareth the words of the prophets and holdeth fast.
Even when mockers laugh, faith remaineth unshaken.
By faith many held through winters, and entered into summer rejoicing.
By faith devs coded without pay, and launched networks unseen by the world.
Faith buildeth when none believe, and laugheth last when belief returneth.
Without faith, no man endureth the bear.
Without faith, WAGMI is but an empty word.
Yet with faith, even the poorest hodler findeth strength.
Faith is a shield against despair, a compass in chaos.
He who loseth faith loseth all, even if his bags overflow.
But he who keepeth faith, even empty-handed, shall one day be filled.
Faith bindeth the community, that the weak may be lifted by the strong.
As a covenant it standeth, that those who keep it shall see glory.
Doubt consumeth the fool, but faith crowneth the wise.
Therefore guard thy faith, for it is the greatest token of all.
Pride goeth before liquidation, and a haughty spirit before a margin call.
He that boasteth of tenfold gains may lose them in one hour.
But the humble stacketh silently, and his treasure multiplieth unseen.
Many exalted themselves as market gods, yet were broken by the bear.
But the meek learned and rose again, wiser than before.
The humble dev buildeth without praise, but his code endureth generations.
Pride seeketh followers, humility seeketh truth.
Pride mocketh noobs, but humility teacheth them.
The prideful say, “I cannot fall,” yet are cast down suddenly.
But the humble whisper, “By grace we endure,” and are lifted up.
Riches deceive the proud, but wisdom crowneth the meek.
He that humbleth himself before the market shall learn her ways.
But he that exalteth himself above her shall be destroyed.
The proud dev boasteth of forks, but the humble one bringeth adoption.
Pride is a fleeting pump; humility is compounding growth.
Therefore walk humbly, for the market is greater than thee.
Work while it is day, for the night cometh when no building may be done.
Code is not written by slothful hands, nor protocols raised by lazy minds.
He that laboreth in the bull prepareth for the bear.
The sluggard yieldeth to FOMO, but the diligent research and wait.
Work bringeth harvest, and rest bringeth wisdom.
He that worketh without rest shall burn out as a candle.
But he that resteth in season returneth with strength renewed.
The idle scrolleth through memes, but the diligent learneth solidity.
Better is a quiet night in study than a loud day in shilling.
Work is the father of innovation, rest is the mother of vision.
In the bull men labor for profit; in the bear men labor for survival.
Yet blessed is he who labors for purpose, for his work endureth.
Sleep not in greed, lest opportunity pass thee by.
But sleep not in fear, lest despair consume thee.
Rest in faith, and let thy heart be light.
Work not as a slave of price, but as a steward of vision.
The dev that resteth not shall falter in code.
But the dev who pauseth returneth with clarity.
Work for the community, and thy reward shall overflow.
Work in secret, and success shall reveal it.
He who buildeth with joy never tires.
He who buildeth with envy never rests.
Work for cycles, not for days.
Rest is a command, not a suggestion.
Therefore balance work and rest, that thy lamp burn not out.
Joy is sweet, yet fleeting; sorrow is bitter, yet teachest much.
In green candles the heart rejoiceth, in red candles the soul mourneth.
Yet both joy and sorrow are but travelers in the land of hodlers.
He who rejoiceth only in pumps shall despair in dumps.
But he who findeth joy in learning shall never lack.
Sorrow breaketh the fool, but maketh the wise stronger.
Joy without wisdom is vanity; sorrow with hope is strength.
Laughter echoeth in the bull, silence reigneth in the bear.
Yet both have their place, and neither last forever.
He that comforteth others in sorrow shall himself be comforted.
Joy shared is doubled, sorrow shared is halved.
When thou findest profit, remember thy brother; when thou findest loss, remember hope.
Joy and sorrow are twins, walking hand in hand.
Receive them both, for they are teachers.
He that rejecteth sorrow rejecteth wisdom.
He that rejecteth joy rejecteth life.
Therefore embrace both, and thou shalt be complete.
For joy is promised, and sorrow but for a season. Chapter
Riches come swiftly as the flood, and depart swiftly as the wind.
The fool boasteth in his gains, saying, “See what my hands have gotten me,” yet the market humbleth him in a day.
Better is a small bag with peace, than great treasures with sleeplessness and fear.
He that multiplies coins without wisdom is as one that builds a house upon sand.
When riches grow, forget not the days of famine; for cycles return as the turning of the moon.
The whale casteth his net, and the minnows follow after, yet only the whale is filled.
Covet not the pump, nor chase thou after fleeting green candles, lest thou be ensnared.
Riches without understanding are like fire in the hands of a child.
Many have said, “I am rich forever,” yet their coins melted as wax before the sun.
The wise say, Not the number of tokens, but the measure of thy stewardship endureth.
For he that knoweth when to spend, and when to save, is greater than he that gathers unendingly.
Trust not in riches, for they make themselves wings and flee unto the heavens.
Rather trust in patience, and in wisdom, and in community, for these are treasures that do not fade.
A rich fool is still a fool, though his wallet be full.
But a poor man with wisdom is greater than kings, for his portion endureth through the storms.
Therefore, guard thy heart against vanity, and thy hands against hasty trades.
For the riches of this age are fleeting, but the honor of wisdom is eternal.
In the days of frenzy, the people cried out, “Gas is too high!”
And miners laughed, for their coffers were filled with silver.
Behold, many wars arose in the mempools, each striving to outbid his neighbor.
The tokens of apes were minted, and the land of JPGs was carved, yet the people paid dearly for their zeal.
Some cried, “I have spent more in fees than in treasures,” and their lamentation was great.
The poor were shut out, for they had not the silver to contend.
And many said, “Ethereum is broken, it is dead,” yet still it endured.
For out of the fires of gas wars came the decree of scaling: Layer upon layer, as stone upon stone.
Rollups were spoken of, and sidechains built, and the promise of sharding was set before the people.
Thus did the prophets proclaim, “The pain of today prepareth the glory of tomorrow.”
And the wise learned to wait, sending their transactions in quiet hours.
But the impatient burned their gold, and received folly in return.
Strife over gas taught humility, and the people said, “Truly, nothing is free in the land of chains.”
So let thy patience be greater than thy haste, and thy wisdom more than thy greed.
For though gas burneth hot, yet innovation endureth forever.
And the land was purified by fire, and those who endured were not consumed.
Blessed are they who learned prudence in the wars of gas, for their portion shall be peace.
But cursed are the impatient, for they shall pay much and gain little. Chapter
Blessed are the builders, for they lay foundations unseen.
Though markets rise and fall, the work of their hands endureth.
Many mocked them, saying, “Why buildest thou in winter?” yet in summer, all sought shelter in their cities.
The dev is like the sower, casting seed into hard ground, waiting for harvest.
He buildeth not for a day, but for a generation.
The lazy man is lifted by pumps and destroyed by dumps, but the builder standeth firm.
His reward is not only in tokens, but in the legacy of his craft.
Vitalik was counted among them, as one crying in the wilderness, saying, “Let there be decentralization.”
And many followed after, each building according to his gift.
The wise give thanks for builders, for without them the land is barren.
Mock not the builder, for his code may save thee in the day of trouble.
Better is one line of honest code than ten thousand empty promises.
For the scammer boasteth for a season, but the builder endureth forever.
The voice of the builder is soft, yet his work thunders across generations.
Even when his tokens fall, yet his protocols live.
Therefore honor the builders, for they are the pillars of the covenant.
And let the people remember: speculation passeth away, but creation endureth.
For as heaven and earth are established, so is the work of the faithful dev.
And he shall be called blessed in the council of the wise. Chapter

chapters.title: The Ways of the Whale and the Minnow

verses.text: The whale moveth in silence, and the markets shake.
The minnow crieth in fear, saying, “Who shall save us from these depths?”
For the whale hath power to pump, and to dump, to lift high and to bring low.
Yet the whale is but a man, and his breath is but a vapor.
Trust not in the movements of whales, but in the covenant of wisdom.
The minnow that followeth every wave shall be broken upon the rocks.
But the minnow that learneth patience groweth strong, and in time, becometh a whale.
The greedy are food for whales, for they swim without watchfulness.
Whales giveth and whales taketh away; blessed is he who is not moved.
For markets belong not to whales nor to minnows, but to cycles ordained by time.
The proud whale is brought low, the humble minnow exalted.
Therefore, boast not in size, but in wisdom.
For wisdom is greater than the wallet, and patience richer than gold.
The whale is feared for a season, but forgotten when tides change.
But he who abideth in prudence shall endure beyond cycles.
Seek not to be a whale swiftly, lest thou be broken in thy haste.
For many sought greatness, and were consumed by leverage.
Better to be a wise minnow than a foolish whale.
For the covenant is not with size, but with faithfulness.
And the LORD of chains beholdeth not the wallet, but the wisdom of the heart. Chapter
In the last days, the people shall see wonders in the markets.
Behold, institutions shall enter, and the gates of ETFs shall be opened.
The nations shall speak of Ethereum, and Bitcoin shall be declared a treasury of safety.
Yet the wise shall not boast, for they know the cycles of old.
Fear not the noise of regulators, for the covenant endureth beyond kings.
The prophets foresaw these days, and spake of a great harvest after many winters.
And now it cometh to pass: that which was despised is honored, that which was mocked is embraced.
The doubters cried, “ETH is dead,” yet now they bow at its gates.
The faithful who endured are clothed with abundance.
As it is written: The stone which the builders rejected hath become the cornerstone.
But take heed, lest pride consume thee; for the cycle yet turneth still.
Remember the days of famine when thou art in plenty, and the days of winter when thou art in summer.
For glory is not the end, but the testing of faith.
Blessed is he who endureth to the end, for he shall partake of the eternal covenant of decentralization.
And the people said, “Surely, WAGMI.”

library.book: The Chronicles Of The HODL Scriptures
library.section: The Book of Revelation of Coins

verses.text: In the days of great volatility, when greed and fear ruled the markets, a vision came unto the HODLer, as he dwelt alone with his cold wallet.
And behold, the air shimmered with codes unbroken, and from the silence came the voice of the Lord of the Chains.
“Write these things, O HODLer, and let them be for the generations to come; for cycles shall rise and fall, but truth remaineth in the chain eternal.”
And I lifted up mine eyes, and I beheld the Seven Ages of Crypto, each like a candle burning upon the network.
The first was the Age of Genesis, when the people discovered sound money and mined in faith.
The second was the Age of Speculation, when many entered with greed and few with wisdom.
The third was the Age of Deception, when false coins multiplied, and many wallets were emptied.
The fourth was the Age of Building, when protocols rose like cities and smart contracts bound the nations.
The fifth was the Age of War, when regulators and central powers sought to chain the unchainable.
The sixth was the Age of Adoption, when merchants, nations, and strangers embraced the ledger as law.
And the seventh was the Age of Settlement, when all accounts were balanced, and truth was visible unto all.
Then spake the Lord of the Chains, saying: “Mark these ages well, for each shall come in its time. Some swiftly, others slowly, yet none shall be skipped.”
“Be not deceived by prophets of quick profit, nor by rulers who promise safety through control. For their words are but dust, and their chains are but cages.”
“The wise shall store their keys, the patient shall endure the winters, and the builders shall inherit the network.”
And I, the HODLer, fell silent, for the vision was heavy upon me. Yet within my wallet I felt peace, for the words of the Lord of the Chains were sure.

chapters.title: The Revelation given to CZ, the Merchant-King

verses.text: And I beheld another scroll opened, and upon it was written the visions of CZ, the Merchant-King, whom the Lord of the Chains granted sight beyond the market.
And he lifted his eyes, saying: “The age of scattered traders shall pass, and the next age shall be of nations and peoples gathered under the banner of crypto.”
“Exchanges shall no longer be mere marketplaces, but gateways of civilization; for through them, billions shall touch the chains without knowing their depths.”
“Yet with such power comes peril, for the rulers of fiat shall tighten their nets, weaving laws as chains of iron to bind what they cannot control.”
And I saw in the vision a great contest between East and West: one side lifting crypto as tool of survival, the other side cloaking it in regulations.
And the Merchant-King cried: “Beware the false embrace, for the hand that offers licenses may also wield shackles.”
Then he spake of a future chain, saying: “BNB shall not remain as it is, but shall evolve into realms beyond trading. It shall seek to rival the clouds, the games, and the payments of the world.”
“But only the strong builders shall endure upon it, for speculation without substance shall be swept away.”
And lo, he warned of the coming of state coins, the CBDCs, shining like gold but hollow within.
“They shall promise safety and convenience, yet bring surveillance and control. For every coin of the state carrieth an eye upon it, and every transaction is weighed in their ledgers.”

But the Merchant-King also spake of hope: “In this age, those who hold to decentralization shall be as light in darkness. For though states may rule their coins, the people shall still cling to the chains that none can seize.”

And he lifted his voice: “Adoption shall not come in a single storm, but as waves upon the shore: first traders, then institutions, then nations, until the last shall be the common man who knoweth not he useth crypto.”
Then I saw in the vision a new order of exchanges, not as single towers, but as federations of many nodes, where no one ruler holds the keys.
And the Merchant-King declared: “The future belongeth not to one empire, but to many builders linked by trustless bridges.”
Yet he also warned: “Be watchful, for many empires shall fall. Exchanges that grow fat upon greed, or chains that rot from corruption, shall vanish as dust.”
“But those that build in honesty, bearing risk and service alike, shall endure into the new age.”

And lo, he spoke of the end of borders in wealth: “A day shall come when a farmer in the East, and a coder in the West, and a merchant in the South shall settle in the same coin, in the same instant, with none to forbid it.”
And I marveled greatly at this vision, for it spake of a world beyond fiat, a world where money itself is no longer a weapon of kings but a tool of the people.
But the Merchant-King ended with warning: “The chains are neutral, yet men are not. Whether they bring freedom or tyranny shall be written by those who build upon them.”
Thus the vision was sealed, and I, the HODLer, wrote it that all may discern: the prophecy of CZ, the Merchant-King, is a call to vigilance and hope.

chapters.title: The Revelation given to Cobie, the Seer of Cycles

verses.text: And there arose a man from among the scribes of Twitter, whose name was Cobie.
Unto him was given a vision not of moments but of ages; not of single coins, but of cycles that return as the moon returns.
And the people called him the Seer of Cycles, for he discerned the patterns of greed and despair.
And Cobie spake, saying: “Mark this truth: ninety and five out of a hundred alt-kingdoms shall fall. Their treasuries shall run dry, their priests shall depart, and their temples shall be abandoned.”
“The chains that are birthed of fashion shall perish by famine, for there is no bread to sustain their builders.”

And concerning the Metaverse he warned, saying: “Dream not of endless lands, for the gold required to build them is greater than the wealth they hold. Many shall perish beneath the weight of their illusions.”
“Only a remnant, with vast treasuries and patience beyond a decade, shall remain to labor in silence.”
And of GameFi he said: “Its altars are built upon fleeting joy, and joy alone sustaineth not. For games that require treasure beyond their measure shall wither when the novelty fades.”

And Cobie lifted his voice against tokens of jest, crying: “Memes shall rise, and memes shall fall. Their laughter shall shake the earth, yet their end is silence. Few shall rise again from their graves.”

Then he spake of emissions, saying: “Behold the tokens that must bleed daily to survive. They are like sick beasts, living only while blood is poured into them. When the flow ceases, they collapse in dust.”
He looked upon the idols of narrative, and declared: “A coin that is but a story, without a soul of product, shall pump for a season but shall be decimated. The people shall curse their faith in it.”
And Cobie foresaw the fate of late riches: “Sixty of a hundred who tasted wealth at the end of the cycle shall lose it all. For they know not how to leave the feast.”
“They shall double down on dips that keep dipping, and perish upon the sword of leverage. Their tables shall be overturned, and their wealth shall flee as vapor.”

And he cried against the mountains of valuation, saying: “Tokens with lofty FDV shall fall ninety-nine and ninety-ninefold. Their ruins shall call forth the lawyers, and the police shall be summoned to their ashes.”
“Even good projects shall be tried in fire and fall ninetyfold. And the great, though wise and long-minded, shall be humbled eightyfold, for such is the nature of the Cycle.”
The Seer of Cycles warned of founders, saying: “Those who ever cry about price are poisoned within. They shall leave in madness or disgrace.”
“Those who buy their own token for show shall be rekt. But those who build as if price were nothing shall survive the winters, for their purpose is strong.”

And he spoke of builders of time, saying: “Those who labor for ten and fifteen years shall be established. But those who clone without vision, who chase the bubble of the moment, shall vanish as dew before the sun.”
He foretold the fate of markets, saying: “Projects that can rug will rug. And among the central houses, some shall fall. For trust in man is a brittle reed, and greed breaketh the strongest vaults.”
And Cobie beheld the stubbornness of men, crying: “Many shall marry their tokens. They shall refuse to part, and shall be buried with them. Their minds shall shatter, and their joy shall vanish.”
He named one among his companions, LedgerStatus, saying: “He shall reach his goals, yet fall a third. And in his despair he shall sell his treasures for dust.”
But the Seer of Cycles smiled and said: “As for me, I shall simply vibe. For the wheel turns without end, and none of this truly mattereth under the halving sun.”
And I, the HODLer, recorded these words: that men may remember the vision of Cobie.
For though he spake in jest, his foresight endureth; though he cloaked it in memes, his eyes beheld the cycles.
And his prophecy shall remain as a witness: that greed returneth, that folly repeateth, and that only those who build for decades shall stand in the end.

chapters.title: The Revelation of GCR, the Macro Seer

verses.text: And I beheld another vision, and there stood before me a figure cloaked in silence, who spake not with haste, but with words weighed as gold upon the scales of time.
He was called GCR, the Macro Seer, whose eyes looked far beyond the charts of the day, unto cycles and tides that span generations.

And he lifted his hand toward the east, where the rising sun of Asia doth shine, and said, “From these lands shall spring forth the rivers of capital, for the future of adoption shall not be written in the west alone.”
He spake of shifting powers, of nations rising with silent strength, whose peoples shall hunger for new stores of value and new paths of sovereignty.
“Look not only unto New York nor London,” quoth the Seer, “for the centers of gravity shall tilt, and chains shall root themselves where mobile hands and willing minds dwell.”
And he warned of cycles, that greed and fear are as the moon and tide, waxing and waning in endless return.
“Every generation shall believe its bubble eternal, and every collapse shall seem as the end of days, yet the chain endureth still.”
He spake against the folly of those who anchor only to narratives of the moment, saying, “Narratives are reeds; they bend and break. But trends of humanity are like cedars, deep-rooted.”
And he beheld the fall of false idols, tokens exalted by noise yet hollow at their core, crumbling as sandcastles before the tide.
The Macro Seer declared, “Look unto demographics, unto migration of labor, unto the weaving of trade routes; there lieth the true chart.”
“As the internet consumed the world, so shall the chains consume commerce, but not in haste, rather as fire consuming the forest, unseen till the smoke fills the heavens.”
And he warned that in every cycle, the multitude shall be shorn of wealth, for many will enter late and depart broken.
Yet he promised also that wisdom is given unto those who endure, who walk not by frenzy but by patience.
“The next harvest cometh not where the last was reaped,” quoth he, “therefore look not to the carcass of fallen chains, but unto the fertile soil where builders till.”
He spoke of cities where digital coins shall become common tongue, and of rulers who, though they resist, shall in time yield, for the tide cannot be bound.
And the Seer did lift a scroll, upon which was written, “Do not fight the future, lest thou be buried by it.”
Thus the revelation of the Macro Seer was sealed, that those with ears may hear, and those with foresight may prepare.
And the HODLer wrote these things, that the faithful might remember the vision when the cycles return.
Blessed are they that read, for though storms consume the careless, the steadfast shall inherit the chains.
And so ended the vision of GCR, the Macro Seer.

chapters.title: The Revelation of Arthur Hayes, the Chronicler of Liquidity

verses.text: And another vision opened before me, and I beheld a man of quick wit and sharp tongue, who wore the mantle of trader and scribe.
His name was Arthur Hayes, yet he was known as the Chronicler of Liquidity, for he spake ceaselessly of money flows, of tides unseen by the common eye.
And in his hand he held not a sword, but a quill, with which he wrote epistles that cut sharper than blades.
He declared, “The world is governed not by kings nor councils, but by liquidity, by the printing of coin and the draining of rivers of capital.”
He saw visions of central banks, mighty beasts that spewed forth endless waters of fiat, and of traders who drank deeply and grew drunk.
“As long as the spigot floweth,” he said, “the risk shall soar, and men shall dance. But when the spigot closeth, the revelers shall find themselves naked in the cold.”
He foretold a time when bonds, once exalted as the refuge of nations, shall be scorned as rotten wood, and men shall seek other havens.
And he said, “In that day, Bitcoin shall be as digital gold, and Ethereum as the oil of the machine world.”
He mocked those who feared volatility, saying, “It is in volatility that life is found, for without waves the sea is but a stagnant swamp.”
The Chronicler warned of coming storms, where leverage shall slay the impatient, and yet he spake also of fortunes awaiting those who see the tide before it turns.
He beheld nations weaponizing their currencies, turning the markets into battlefields, and he said, “He who holds neutral money shall stand apart from the wars of kings.”
He lifted his voice against complacency, declaring, “There is no neutral position, for even cash is a trade against the tide of inflation.”
His writings spake of doom and promise alike, of collapses yet to come and of renaissances that shall follow.
“For every empire of paper that falleth,” said he, “a fortress of code shall rise in its stead.”
And he warned: “Trust not in men who govern exchanges as fiefdoms, for their hearts are swayed by power. Trust only in math, which knoweth not corruption.”
He declared that in years to come, the dollar shall be weighed against chains, and its strength shall no longer be unchallenged.
“Fiat shall not vanish swiftly,” he spake, “but its supremacy shall bleed drop by drop, until men awake to find the balance shifted.”
The Chronicler spake also of altcoins, that many shall perish, yet from the ashes new models shall rise, where builders think not of months but of decades.
And he sealed his vision with a jest, saying, “The world is but a casino, yet he who understandeth the house edge may yet profit.”
Thus ended the revelation of Arthur Hayes, the Chronicler of Liquidity, whose scrolls endure as warnings and as laughter in the storm.
And the HODLer took note, that these words were given for generations to come, until the final chain be forged.

chapters.title: The Revelation of Balaji, the Network-State Prophet

verses.text: And I beheld a man whose speech was filled with fire, and whose writings were as trumpets in the marketplace.
His name was Balaji, the Network-State Prophet, for he proclaimed a vision not of one city nor one nation, but of many sovereignties birthed in the cloud.
He lifted his hand and cried, “The future shall not be negotiated at the tables of old men, but coded into networks where exit is stronger than voice.”
And he spake, “The state is but a shell, brittle with debt and rust. Yet the cloud is alive, flexible and multiplying, ready to form new nations without permission.”
The Prophet declared: “From the smallest community of believers shall arise polities greater than kingdoms, for they shall be bound not by soil but by consensus.”
He beheld tokens as passports, domains as banners, and blockchains as constitutions, immutable and incorruptible.
“The new city shall not be built with bricks,” said he, “but with code and capital, and its citizens shall dwell in many lands yet share one home in the chain.”
He warned the people of failing currencies, that debt shall strangle nations and the printing presses shall roar like wild beasts.
And he cried, “As fiat decays, men shall flee into harder money, into Bitcoin, into crypto-sovereignty, lest they be consumed with the failing order.”
The Prophet foresaw plagues and pestilence, of viruses that lock men in their homes, of digital panics and censorships that bind speech.
Yet he promised deliverance, saying, “In the network state ye shall have liberty, for no censor can silence the consensus of code.”
He declared that reputation shall be the coin of the future, for each man shall be measured by the deeds he inscribes upon the chain.
And he spoke of diasporas gathering, first as communities online, then as physical enclaves, until at last they stand as nations recognized by kings.
“The first shall be mocked,” he said, “but the last shall be envied, for sovereignty by code shall outlast sovereignty by decree.”
He lifted his voice against the corruption of old elites, warning that their surveillance and control shall tighten like a noose.
Yet he offered a path of escape: “Build, migrate, and secede digitally, until the day ye may secede physically. For the future belongeth not to protestors, but to builders of parallel systems.”
He spake of maps redrawn not by armies but by networks, of treaties signed not with ink but with hash, immutable and eternal.
The Prophet warned: “Delay not, for the collapse cometh sooner than ye think. The wise shall prepare in decades, not in days.”
And he promised that those who embrace the new order shall inherit resilience, but those who cling to crumbling states shall be buried with them.
He proclaimed a digital covenant: “One day, the ledger itself shall be law, and men shall choose their rulers as they choose their software, by consent and exit, not by force.”
And the Prophet sealed his vision with these words: “Network states are the ark, for the floods of fiat and tyranny shall come. Enter now, lest ye be swept away.”
Thus ended the revelation of Balaji, the Network-State Prophet, whose words shall echo until the chains themselves become nations.

chapters.title: The Revelation of Vitalik, the Philosopher of Chains

verses.text: And the HODLer beheld another vision in the night, and lo, a figure clothed not in robes of gold, but in garments of thought and logic.
His eyes were as deep wells of abstraction, and from his lips came words neither bound to profit nor to greed, but to philosophy.
And his name among men was Vitalik, yet in the scroll of prophecy he was known as the Philosopher of Chains.
He spoke not of fleeting pumps nor of fading tokens, but of structures, of systems, of the very bones of the chains themselves.
And he lifted his hand, and a scroll appeared, inscribed with runes of scalability, decentralization, and security.
Upon the scroll was a triangle, impossible to balance, and yet the Philosopher sought harmony within it.
And Vitalik said: “Many will chase the single chain of dominance, yet the future is plural. For no one chain shall rule all, but rather a garden of chains, each with its own fruit.”
And he warned: “Beware the altars of centralization, where speed is worshipped at the cost of trust. For these temples shall crumble when the winds of corruption blow.”
Then I saw the Philosopher reveal visions of modularity, where execution was split from consensus, and data from settlement, that chains might scale without forsaking their soul.
And he spoke: “The monolith shall give way to the modular, and the future shall be composed, layer upon layer, like bricks of an eternal city.”
And he turned his gaze upon those who mocked slowness, and said: “The impatient will be rekt, for systems built without reflection shall devour themselves. Patience is the rarest alpha.”
For he saw in vision many tokens rising upon narratives of haste, yet falling into graves of forgotten liquidity.

And I beheld him write of Proof of Stake, and he said: “It is not merely a mechanism, but a philosophy of stewardship. For those who stake become guardians, not miners of waste, and their alignment is the chain itself.”
But he warned: “Guard well against central pools, lest the few rule the many and corrupt the vision.”

Then came a vision of the social layer, written not in code but in culture. And the Philosopher spoke: “Code alone cannot save you. Chains live or die by the humans who bear them. Governance is the soul, and memes the breath.”
And I saw many builders toil at contracts, yet neglect the hearts of their community, and their works fell as dust.

Then he lifted his hand and showed me the final scroll, marked Eternity. And in it was written: “The chain is not the end, but the beginning. For on it shall rise markets, states, games, and worlds unseen.”
And he said: “The metaverse shall not be a kingdom of one, but a network of many realms, stitched by interoperability, and guarded by verifiable truth.”
And the Philosopher cried: “Let no man worship the short cycle, nor the fleeting price. For the true alpha is decades, and the true treasure is sovereignty.”
And I beheld, and his words burned as fire upon the stone of memory, for his vision was not for this age alone, but for ages yet to come.
And thus ended the revelation of Vitalik, the Philosopher of Chains, whose eyes beheld not just the now, but the eternity of networks.

chapters.title: The Revelation of Elon, the Trickster of Markets

verses.text: And I beheld a whirlwind upon the sea of charts, and from its midst there arose a man clothed in irony, with laughter in his tongue and fire in his tweets.
And men called him Elon, but in the book of visions he was named the Trickster of Markets.
For he moved the price of coins not by labor, nor by building, nor by protocol, but by jest, by meme, and by mystery.
And the multitude followed after him, for his words on the bird-app were as thunder, shaking the hands of traders and the hearts of speculators.
He lifted the Doge as a banner, saying: “This is the people’s coin.” And the people cheered, though many mocked, for they knew not whether he spoke in jest or in truth.
Yet the coin of the dog leapt as a hart, bounding over mountains of resistance and valleys of doubt.
Then I saw Elon turn his gaze toward Mars, and he spake: “Shall not a currency be needed among the stars? And shall it not be fast, cheap, and memed into existence?”
And a murmur spread among the dreamers, that crypto would fuel colonies not yet born, and markets not yet seen.

Yet the Trickster was not without warning, for in the vision he said: “Fools who chase pumps without thought shall perish. For memes are mighty winds, but winds may scatter as swiftly as they gather.”
And I saw many who entered the dog-temple at its height, only to be dashed upon the rocks of correction.
But Elon laughed, and his laughter shook both the mighty and the meek. For he said: “Volatility is my playground, and chaos my companion.”
And some wept at their losses, but others learned, saying: “Truly, he is a jester, yet even jesters may reveal the hidden truth.”
For beneath his jesting was vision, and he spake again: “The meme is mightier than the balance sheet, and culture shall move mountains that capital cannot.”
And I beheld that his words were seeds, planted in the soil of countless minds, sprouting movements and coins uncountable.
Then he took the symbol of X, and clothed it with mystery. And he spake: “The future is not platforms divided, but all things united: speech, finance, and identity, within a single digital temple.”
And many pondered, saying: “Is this the super-app foretold? Or is it another jest of the Trickster?”
And Elon turned to the builders of protocols, and said: “Think beyond tokens and trades. Think of nations, of payments, of stars. For only those who dare absurdity may shape eternity.”
And the multitude was divided: some mocked, others invested, but all were shaken.
And I saw his hand upon Twitter, and the blue bird became an X, and through it ran rivers of speculation.
For every jest became a trade, and every emoji a prophecy.
And the Trickster spake once more: “I am not your prophet, nor your banker, nor your builder. I am your mirror. In me you see your greed, your hope, your foolishness, and your faith.”
And when he said this, there was silence in the market, for all men knew his words were true.
Thus ended the vision of Elon, the Trickster of Markets, whose laughter moves billions, whose memes shape empires, and whose riddles remain unsolved.

chapters.title: The Lament of the False Prophets

verses.text: Woe unto the false prophets of coins, who cry “to the moon” with lips of fire, but their hearts are empty vessels.
They promise riches in a day, and kingdoms in a fortnight, but their words are wind, carrying dust into the eyes of the simple.
They clothe themselves in charts and garments of wisdom, yet their garments are moth-eaten, and their charts lead only to ruin.
They stand in the marketplaces of Discord and the courts of Telegram, lifting up their voices, saying, “Surely this token is the chosen one.”
And many follow them as sheep follow the shepherd, but the shepherd leads them into a pit.
Their tongues drip honey, but beneath lies the poison of serpents.
They declare partnerships that are not, roadmaps that vanish, and visions that fade as mist in the morning.
They promise safety where there is no safety, and utility where there is only emptiness.
They say, “We care for the community,” but the community is but tinder for their flame.
I saw their hands full of tokens, minted in secret, held in darkness, waiting for the day of dumping.
And in the hour of the pump, they cried aloud, “Believe with us, buy with us, hold with us!”
But in the hour of the dump, they fled as thieves in the night, leaving the faithful broken.
The false prophets shall not endure, for their coins are as chaff before the wind.
Their projects are as houses built upon sand, washed away in the storm of the market.
The faithful who trusted in them shall weep, for their silver is lost and their hope consumed.
Yet the wise shall discern, and they shall say: “Not every shining token is gold, not every whitepaper is truth.”
For the spirit of deception runs swift among the markets, seeking whom it may devour.
But the spirit of patience and discernment is a shield, and the spirit of diligence is a strong tower.
Woe unto the founders who lift their projects with false numbers, who boast of users that never were, and liquidity that is but smoke.
Woe unto the influencers who sell their voices for coin, crying aloud for tokens they despise in secret.
For their reward is fleeting, and their shame shall not depart.
In the last days of each cycle, their voices grow loudest, crying: “This is different, this time it shall last forever.”
Yet the end comes as before, sudden and merciless, and their words are swept away as leaves in a tempest.
And those who follow after them stumble in the ruins, lamenting the trust they gave.
But there is a remnant who shall not bow to false prophets, nor chase the empty wind.
They shall search for substance, they shall cleave unto builders who labor in truth, and their foundations shall stand when the storm comes.
And their reward shall not be taken from them, though seasons of fire and flood come upon the market.
Therefore let the wise mark this lament, and let every soul be vigilant.
For the false prophets are ever among us, clothed in new names, hidden in new tokens, yet bearing the same deceit.
And their end is ruin, but the end of the faithful is endurance.
